data.title: Jamal Crawford gets the role, and journey, he wanted with the Timberwolves
data.meta_description: Jamal Crawford joined the Minnesota Timberwolves because he wanted the journey of growing with an up-and-coming Wolves team. Even at age 37, Crawford, one of the game's elite bench scorers, feels he's got plenty of gas left in the tank.
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

Jamal Crawford had options this summer.

After receiving a buyout from the Atlanta Hawks, the veteran guard could have gone to a surefire NBA championship contender such as the Cavaliers and potentially played a big role while helping LeBron James bring another title to Cleveland.

Instead, Crawford chose the Timberwolves, who haven’t been in the playoffs since 2004.

“I just felt good about what was happening,” Crawford said in a phone interview Saturday.

He knows Wolves coach Tom Thibodeau, played with assistant coach Rick Brunson, worked closely with assistant general manager Noah Croom when Croom was an agent and has played with guys like Jeff Teague and Cole Aldrich. Crawford knows how good guys like Karl-Anthony Towns and Andrew Wiggins are and took notice when Minnesota added Jimmy Butler, Taj Gibson and Jeff Teague this offseason.

“I’m like, ‘They’re for real,’” Crawford said, “and I just felt with my role and how my fit was, it just made sense on every level.

“Obviously, I could’ve went to a championship contender or a team that was right there already, but I wanted to really just embrace the journey.”

Crawford wants to be there for those times when Minnesota is on the road, playing its fourth game in five days and has to “find a way to win.” His appreciates those games, those moments of growth. While Minnesota went from a young, inexperienced team to a group that’s getting older each day, Crawford sees a chance to grow with the core the Wolves have assembled.

A quick look at Crawford’s age would suggest he’s done growing. He’s 37. He’s spent 17 years in the NBA. But, to Crawford, those numbers don’t mean much.

“I know my age is one thing, but my actual play is something else to me,” he said. “I always joke that I’m 47 mentally and 27 physically, so I guess that’s how they came up with 37. Other than that, I just really felt like I could grow with the team and feel like a leadership role would be there, not only with my voice, but also on and off the court.”

Crawford said he’s in a “unique position,” because many guys his age have hit a point where their play has fallen off and their role is to sit on the end of the bench be good locker room guys.

“There’s nothing wrong with that,” he said, “because everybody will probably get there at some point.”

But Crawford doesn’t feel like he’s close to that stage.

“I just know myself, I know my body, I know how I’ve prepared and I know how to take care of myself,” said Crawford, while on his way to his Seattle summer league he plays in each week. “I just know shape has no age. When you’re feeling good, you’re in shape, if you saw me play, you wouldn’t say he’s 37. You may say he’s mid-20s or whatever. That’s just a number, really.”

Even at 37, Crawford is intent on continuing to improve his game, one of the reasons he’s excited to play for Tom Thibodeau, despite the coach’s reputation as a relentless pusher who barks from the opening tip to the final buzzer.

“You hear his voice, you can hear it through the TV, but I don’t look at that as glass half-empty, I look at it as half-full,” Crawford said. “Because, you know what, he’s going to push me outside my comfort zone, and if I’m open to that, then I’ll be a better player, because I’ll be willing to grow as a player. And if I’m a better player, then I’ll be better for the Minnesota Timberwolves. I think they all correlate and I think he’ll help my game grow and continue to grow, and, for me, that’s exciting.”

Those who believe Crawford is on the slide point to his slipping scoring averages over the past couple seasons. Crawford said that’s a product of his role. The Clippers added more scorers off the bench the last couple seasons, and Crawford’s minutes and shot attempts were affected.

“It all correlated,” Crawford said. “You can’t say, ‘Oh, he’s a good team player by sacrificing,’ then on the other end say, ‘Oh, his numbers dipped.’ Well obviously it dipped if I’m sacrificing some of my game.”

Crawford has proven he can still turn it on when needed. When things weren’t going well for the Clippers’ second unit mid-way through the 2015-16 season, Crawford said coach Doc Rivers asked him to be more aggressive. Crawford went on a tear down the stretch, which resulted in him winning his third Sixth Man of the Year award.

“He’s had a lot of big games. If you go through his game log from last season, you see that he’s had big games against a lot of really good teams, and it doesn’t take him much to get going, and that’s the way he’s always been,” Thibodeau said last week. “I know when we’ve played against him, you always worry about when he comes in and hits those first two shots, you could be in trouble.”

In that way, Crawford is the prototypical bench scorer, capable of providing points in bunches. Crawford’s name is now the reference when teams talk about needing a scoring punch off the bench. That’s something he takes pride in, though he didn’t start coming off the bench until he went to Atlanta in 2009. The role seems like the perfect fit for Crawford.

He should get to fully immerse himself in it again in Minnesota. While the Timberwolves continue to add pieces to provide much improved depth, Crawford should easily be their top reserve scorer and will certainly be the offensive focal point of the second unit.

“To hear that I could be back in that feature role off the bench, I’m really, really excited,” Crawford said. “And that doesn’t mean I take every shot or anything like that, it just means you do what you do best.”

Whatever it takes to win, Crawford said.

“It’s weird, in my mind, in my heart, I know how this season is going to play out for our team,” he said. “I just feel really, really good about what’s going on moving forward.”

Originally Published: July 15, 2017 at 5:23 p.m.
